elements.content: Acidification (pH = 3) of a solution containing AgNO3 with 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2BDC) and 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe) (molar ratio = 1:1:1) with 6 M HNO3 followed by hydrothermal treatment at 170 °C afforded a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer {[Ag2(bpe)2](1,4-BDC)·(1,4-H2BDC)} n (1). Photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction of 1 through UV irradiation followed by dissolving the photolysis product in 6 M HNO3 and hydrothermal treatment at 170 °C led to the formation of a three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymer {[Ag4(4,4′-tpcb)3][(NO3)4(H2O)6]} n (4,4′-tpcb = tetrakis(4-pyridyl)-cyclobutane) (2). Compounds 1 and 2 were characterized by elemental analysis, IR, and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 consists of a 1D linear chain extending along the [011] plane in which Ag(I) ions are bridged by bpe molecules. Compound 2 contains the 2-fold interpenetrating 3D cationic [Ag4(4,4′-tpcb)3] n 4n+ net with the Schlafli symbol of (63)4(6284)3. Within the cages of this net occupy the uncommon nitrate-water cluster [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4− anions. The formation of such a cluster anion may provide some insight into the nature of hydration of nitrate in H2O.

The formation of such a cluster anion may provide some insight into the nature of hydration of nitrate in H2O.

elements.content: Photochemical [2 + 2] cycloaddition reaction of a one-dimensional polymer {[Ag2(bpe)2](1,4-BDC)·(1,4-H2BDC)} n through UV irradiation followed by a hydrothermal treatment of a solution derived from dissolving the photolysis product in 6 M HNO3 led to the formation of a three-dimensional (3D) polymer {[Ag4(4,4′-tpcb)3][(NO3)4(H2O)6]} n in which unique nitrate-water cluster [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4− anions are encapsulated into the cages of a 3D two-fold interpenetrating cationic [Ag4(4,4′-tpcb)3] n 4n+ net.

elements.content: In the past few decades, theoretical and experimental studies of water clusters have aroused considerable attention, and a great variety of discrete water clusters with various topological structures have been reported. On the other hand, inorganic anions play important roles in atmospheric chemistry, inorganic chemistry, geochemistry, and biochemistry. Many chemical and natural processes occur in water and are involved in inorganic anions. The reactivity of the inorganic anions is strongly affected by hydration. Therefore, studies of the hydrated anionic species, that is, anion−water clusters, are of special importance in understanding of the hydration phenomena of inorganic anions in nature and biochemistry. However, only a few examples are involved in discrete inorganic anion−water clusters, and they usually contain only one or two inorganic anions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past few decades, theoretical and experimental studies of water clusters have aroused considerable attention, and a great variety of discrete water clusters with various topological structures have been reported. On the other hand, inorganic anions play important roles in atmospheric chemistry, inorganic chemistry, geochemistry, and biochemistry. Many chemical and natural processes occur in water and are involved in inorganic anions. The reactivity of the inorganic anions is strongly affected by hydration. Therefore, studies of the hydrated anionic species, that is, anion-water clusters, are of special importance in understanding of the hydration phenomena of inorganic anions in nature and biochemistry. However, only a few examples are involved in discrete inorganic anion-water clusters, and they usually contain only one or two inorganic anions.

elements.content: Nitrate is one of the most common inorganic anions existing in nature and is engaged in many natural processes in water. However, reports on discrete nitrate−water clusters have been mainly involved in theoretical calculation models. To this end, we are interested in the preparation of nitrate−water cluster anions and wish to provide models for the interactions of nitrates with water. Thus, we attempted to prepare a cationic framework with cages or grids. Since reactions of metal ions with multidentate ligands are likely to produce coordination polymers with cages, we chose a system consisting of AgNO3/bpe/1,4-H2BDC (bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene; 1,4-H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) and expect to obtain a metal−organic framework with nitrate−water clusters in its crystal lattices. In fact, we isolated a one-dimensional (1D) chain polymer {[Ag2(bpe)2](1,4-BDC)·(1,4-H2BDC)} n (1) through hydrothermal reactions. The UV irradiation of 1 followed by further hydrothermal treatment in HNO3 solution gave rise to {[Ag4(4,4′-tpcb)3][(NO3)4(H2O)6]} n (4,4′-tpcb = tetrakis(4-pyridyl)-cyclobutane) (2) that consists of 2-fold interpenetrating 3D cationic [Ag4(4,4′-tpcb)3] n 4n+ network with unique nitrate−water cluster [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4− anions in its cages. Herein, we report their syntheses, crystal structures, and thermal properties.
elements.clean_text: Nitrate is one of the most common inorganic anions existing in nature and is engaged in many natural processes in water. However, reports on discrete nitrate-water clusters have been mainly involved in theoretical calculation models. To this end, we are interested in the preparation of nitrate-water cluster anions and wish to provide models for the interactions of nitrates with water. Thus, we attempted to prepare a cationic framework with cages or grids. Since reactions of metal ions with multidentate ligands are likely to produce coordination polymers with cages, we chose a system consisting of AgNO3/bpe/1,4-H2BDC (bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene; 1,4-H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) and expect to obtain a metal-organic framework with nitrate-water clusters in its crystal lattices. In fact, we isolated a one-dimensional (1D) chain polymer {[Ag2(bpe)2](1,4-BDC)⋅(1,4-H2BDC)} n  (1) through hydrothermal reactions. The UV irradiation of 1 followed by further hydrothermal treatment in HNO3 solution gave rise to {[Ag4(4,4'-tpcb)3][(NO3)4(H2O)6]} n  (4,4'-tpcb = tetrakis(4-pyridyl)-cyclobutane) (2) that consists of 2-fold interpenetrating 3D cationic [Ag4(4,4'-tpcb)3] n  4n+ network with unique nitrate-water cluster [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4- anions in its cages. Herein, we report their syntheses, crystal structures, and thermal properties.

elements.content: All chemicals and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. The elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Carlo-Erba CHNO-S microanalyzer. The IR spectra were recorded on a Varian 1000 FT-IR spectrometer as KBr disks (4000−400 cm−1). 1H NMR spectra were recorded at ambient temperature on a Varian UNITYplus-400 spectrometer. 1H NMR chemical shifts were referenced to the solvent signal in DMSO-d 6. Thermal analysis was performed with a Perkin-Elmer TGA-7 thermogravimetric analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min and a flow rate of 100 cm3/min (N2). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) were performed using a PANalytical X’Pert PRO MPD system (PW3040/60).
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

All chemicals and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. The elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Carlo-Erba CHNO-S microanalyzer. The IR spectra were recorded on a Varian 1000 FT-IR spectrometer as KBr disks (4000-400 cm-1). 1H NMR spectra were recorded at ambient temperature on a Varian UNITYplus-400 spectrometer. 1H NMR chemical shifts were referenced to the solvent signal in DMSO-d 6. Thermal analysis was performed with a Perkin-Elmer TGA-7 thermogravimetric analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min and a flow rate of 100 cm3/min (N2). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) were performed using a PANalytical X'Pert PRO MPD system (PW3040/60).

elements.content: To a 10 mL Pyrex glass tube was loaded AgNO3 (17 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,4-BDC (17 mg, 0.1 mmol), bpe (18 mg, 0.1 mmol), and 3 mL of H2O. After the pH value was adjusted to 3.0 by addition of HNO3 (6 M), the tube was sealed and heated in an oven to 170 °C for 1 day, and then cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C h−1 to form light yellow blocks of 1, which were washed with ethanol and dried in air. Yield: 29 mg (64% yield based on Ag). Anal. calcd. for C20H15N2O4Ag: C, 52.77; H, 3.32; N, 6.15. Found: C, 52.92; H, 3.11; N, 6.18. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3436m, 3041w, 1689m, 1610s, 1559m, 1504w, 1432m, 1385m, 1255m, 1222w, 1071w, 1024w, 980m, 830s, 803w, 760s, 569m, 554s. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 298 K, TMS): δ = 8.61 (s, 8H, Py−H), 8.01 (s, 8H, Ph−H), 7.63 (d, 8H, Py−H), 7.53 (s, 4H, CHCH).

elements.content: X-ray quality crystals of 1 and 2 were obtained directly from the above preparations. Diffraction intensities of 1 and 2 were collected on a Rigaku Mercury CCD X-ray diffractometer (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å). These crystals were mounted on glass fibers and cooled at 223 K in a liquid nitrogen stream. Cell parameters were refined on all observed reflections by using the program Crystalclear (Rigaku and MSc, Ver. 1.3, 2001). The collected data were reduced by the program CrystalClear, and an absorption correction (multiscan) was applied. The reflection data were also corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Diffraction Crystallography

X-ray quality crystals of 1 and 2 were obtained directly from the above preparations. Diffraction intensities of 1 and 2 were collected on a Rigaku Mercury CCD X-ray diffractometer (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å). These crystals were mounted on glass fibers and cooled at 223 K in a liquid nitrogen stream. Cell parameters were refined on all observed reflections by using the program Crystalclear (Rigaku and MSc, Ver. 1.3, 2001). The collected data were reduced by the program CrystalClear, and an absorption correction (multiscan) was applied. The reflection data were also corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects.

elements.content: The crystal structures of 1 and 2 were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods with the SHELXL-97 program. As discussed later in this paper, each nitrate/water cluster in 2 is located in the relatively larger cage of the [Ag4(4,4′-tpcb)3] n 4n+ net, which causes the C, N, and O atoms of this cluster to have comparatively high anisotropic temperature factors if they are refined anisotropically. To this end, all the atoms of the nitrate/water cluster were refined isotropically. All other non-hydrogen atoms in 1 and 2 were refined anisotropically. The H atoms of the water solvent molecule in 2 were located from the Fourier map. All hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically idealized positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. A summary of key crystallographic information for 1 and 2 was given in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1 and 2 are listed in Table .

Acidification of a mixture of AgNO3, 1,4-BDC, and bpe (molar ratio = 1:1:1) using 6 M HNO3 (pH = 3) followed by a hydrothermal treatment at 170 °C afforded the crystals of 1 in 64% yield. It is noted that the charge of such cationic chain is balanced not by NO3 − but by 1,4-BDC dianion. The formation of 1 without encapsulating any nitrates or water clusters was discouraging to us. However, 1 may undergo further photoreactions (Scheme ) because two neighboring olefinic double bonds of bpe molecules within the double chain in 1 are parallel to each other with a separation of 3.780 Å, which meets the criteria for a [2 + 2] cycloaddition in the solid state.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Acidification of a mixture of AgNO3, 1,4-BDC, and bpe (molar ratio = 1:1:1) using 6 M HNO3 (pH = 3) followed by a hydrothermal treatment at 170 °C afforded the crystals of 1 in 64% yield. It is noted that the charge of such cationic chain is balanced not by NO3 - but by 1,4-BDC dianion. The formation of 1 without encapsulating any nitrates or water clusters was discouraging to us. However, 1 may undergo further photoreactions (Scheme ) because two neighboring olefinic double bonds of bpe molecules within the double chain in 1 are parallel to each other with a separation of 3.780 Å, which meets the criteria for a [2 + 2] cycloaddition in the solid state.

elements.clean_text: 1  Photochemical Conversion of 1 to 1a by UV Irradiation

elements.content: To this end, either the yellowish single crystal or crystalline powder was packed in between two pyrex glass slides and irradiated for 5 h using a 360 nm Hg lamp (400 W) which afforded a yellow product 1a. The conversion was 100% complete, which was confirmed by 1H NMR (). The 1H NMR spectrum of 1a in DMSO-d 6 was clean and did not show the sharp signal of olefinic protons of 1 at δ 7.53 ppm but a new sharp single resonance at δ 4.66 ppm that was assigned to be protons of cyclobutane. The powder XRD pattern of 1a is almost identical to the simulated and observed ones of 1 (), which implied that the main framework of 1 was maintained after UV irradiation. In addition, the IR spectroscopy () and the elemental analysis of 1a are similar to those of 1. The chemical formula of 1a is tentatively assumed to be {[Ag2(4,4′-tpcb)](1,4-BDC)·(1,4-H2BDC)} n . Attempts to form single crystals of 1a failed because its single crystals always cracked upon UV irradiation. Therefore, we employed hydrothermal methods to grow single crystals of 1a. Since carboxylic anions can accept protons and form carboxylate acid under strong acidic conditions, it is possible to remove the 1,4-BDC anions from 1a via concentrated HNO3, which may have the chance to introduce nitrate into the cationic framework. Adjusting the pH value (pH = 1.2) of the water suspension of 1a by 6 M HNO3 followed by a procedure similar to that used in the isolation of 1 gave rise to an unexpected complex 2 in 34% yield. Relative to the chemical formula of 2, 1a lost the 1,4-BDC anions and the 1,4-H2BDC molecules, while nitrates and water molecules did appear as counter-anions and lattice molecules in 2. We assumed that the added HNO3 dissolved 1a and the resulting components Ag+, 4,4′-tpcb, and NO3 − were reassembled into 2 during the hydrothermal reactions. Attempts to create 2 from reactions of AgNO3 with 4,4′-tpcb under the same conditions failed. It should be noted that MacGillivray and co-workers first took advantage of Ag as a metal ion to orient olefins for [2 + 2] cycloaddition and established the use of products of solid-state reactions as ligands in coordination chemistry. The presence of the water molecules and nitrates were also confirmed by IR spectroscopy and TGA curves (). Solid 1, 1a, and 2 are stable toward air and moisture and insoluble in common organic solvents. The elemental analysis was consistent with the chemical formula of the three compounds. The identities of 1 and 2 were further confirmed by X-ray crystallography.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and each asymmetric unit contains half of a [Ag(bpe)]2 2+ dication, half of a 1,4-BDC2− dianion, and half of a 1,4-H2BDC molecule. As shown in Figure a, Ag(I) ions are bridged by bpe molecules to form a 1D linear chain extending along the [011] plane. In the crystal of 1, two 1D chains are parallel and are weakly held together by argentophilic interactions (Ag···Ag = 3.313 Å) and π···π interactions between pyridyl groups (3.724 Å), forming a 1D ladder-like chain (Figure a). The O(1) and O(1A) atoms of a 1,4-BDC2− dianion weakly bind to Ag(1) in one double chain and Ag(1A) in another double chain (Ag···O = 2.864 Å), forming a 2D (4,4) layer (Figure b). The protonated and deprotonated carboxylate groups work as the hydrogen bond donors and acceptors to link the 2D layers into a 3D hydrogen-bonded net with cavities of dimensions 10.18 × 13.67 × 16.04 Å3. The void space in 1 is further filled by the interpenetration of the other net, thereby forming a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D hydrogen-bonded structure with a Schlafli symbol 41263 (Figure c,d).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 1 

Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and each asymmetric unit contains half of a [Ag(bpe)]2 2+ dication, half of a 1,4-BDC2- dianion, and half of a 1,4-H2BDC molecule. As shown in Figure a, Ag(I) ions are bridged by bpe molecules to form a 1D linear chain extending along the [011] plane. In the crystal of 1, two 1D chains are parallel and are weakly held together by argentophilic interactions (Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag = 3.313 Å) and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between pyridyl groups (3.724 Å), forming a 1D ladder-like chain (Figure a). The O(1) and O(1A) atoms of a 1,4-BDC2- dianion weakly bind to Ag(1) in one double chain and Ag(1A) in another double chain (Ag⋅⋅⋅O = 2.864 Å), forming a 2D (4,4) layer (Figure b). The protonated and deprotonated carboxylate groups work as the hydrogen bond donors and acceptors to link the 2D layers into a 3D hydrogen-bonded net with cavities of dimensions 10.18 × 13.67 × 16.04 Å3. The void space in 1 is further filled by the interpenetration of the other net, thereby forming a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D hydrogen-bonded structure with a Schlafli symbol 41263 (Figure c,d).

elements.content: (a) View of the 1D ladder-like [Ag(bpe)] n n+ chain in 1 with 30% thermal ellipsoids. All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) View of the 2D (4,4) net constructed through the Ag···O interactions. (c) The 2-fold interpenetration model constructed through the H-bonding interactions in 1. The red and blue nets represent two symmetry-related interpenetrating nets. (d) A 3D supramolecular net with a Schlafli symbol (41263). The bpe and 1,4-BDC ligands are represented by the red lines.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the cubic space group I4̅3m, and each asymmetric unit contains one-sixth of [Ag6(4,4′-tpcb)4.5]6+ cation and one NO3 − anion and one and a half of H2O solvent molecule. In the cation, each tpcb, located on a −42m symmetry site, binds to four crystallographically equivalent AgI centers (Figure a). Each Ag, which is situated on a site of −3m symmetry, binds to three pyridyl groups belonging to three separate ligands. Neighboring Ag+ ions interconnect bridging 4,4′-tpcb to form large cages with dimensions of 13.72 × 13.72 × 11.37 Å3 (Figure b). These cages connect to each other in three orientations to generate a highly symmetrical 3D framework with 1D channels with a cross-section area of 8.77 × 8.77 Å2 (Figure c). Within the crystal there are two symmetry-related interpenetrating networks, which results in the formation of smaller cages with dimensions of 8.77 × 8.77 × 11.37 Å3 (Figure d). Each of these cages is occupied by the four nitrate counteranions and six water molecules. The striking feature of these guests is that every NO3 − ion connects with three H2O molecules and every H2O molecule is linked by two NO3 − ions via O2−H1W···O1 hydrogen bonds (O2···O1 2.89 Å, O2−H1w···O1 151.7°). These hydrogen bonding interactions form a rare nitrate−water cluster anion [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4−, which has three C 2 axes going through the O atoms of water molecules (Figure e) and four C 3 axes going through the N atoms of the nitrates (Figure f). The symmetry of the [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4− cluster may be caused by the high symmetry of the (3,4)-connected [Ag4(4,4′-tpcb)3] n 4n+ cubic net. Similar facts were observed for the other anion/water clusters such as the [C2O4 2−·(H2O)2] n chain reported by Mak and the [Cl(H2O)4]− cluster reported by Custelcean. To the best of our knowledge, the [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4− cluster anion has not been reported previously.

Crystal Structure of 2 

Compound 2 crystallizes in the cubic space group I4̅3m, and each asymmetric unit contains one-sixth of [Ag6(4,4'-tpcb)4.5]6+ cation and one NO3 - anion and one and a half of H2O solvent molecule. In the cation, each tpcb, located on a -42m symmetry site, binds to four crystallographically equivalent AgI centers (Figure a). Each Ag, which is situated on a site of -3m symmetry, binds to three pyridyl groups belonging to three separate ligands. Neighboring Ag+ ions interconnect bridging 4,4'-tpcb to form large cages with dimensions of 13.72 × 13.72 × 11.37 Å3 (Figure b). These cages connect to each other in three orientations to generate a highly symmetrical 3D framework with 1D channels with a cross-section area of 8.77 × 8.77 Å2 (Figure c). Within the crystal there are two symmetry-related interpenetrating networks, which results in the formation of smaller cages with dimensions of 8.77 × 8.77 × 11.37 Å3 (Figure d). Each of these cages is occupied by the four nitrate counteranions and six water molecules. The striking feature of these guests is that every NO3 - ion connects with three H2O molecules and every H2O molecule is linked by two NO3 - ions via O2-H1W⋅⋅⋅O1 hydrogen bonds (O2⋅⋅⋅O1 2.89 Å, O2-H1w⋅⋅⋅O1 151.7°). These hydrogen bonding interactions form a rare nitrate-water cluster anion [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4-, which has three C 2 axes going through the O atoms of water molecules (Figure e) and four C 3 axes going through the N atoms of the nitrates (Figure f). The symmetry of the [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4- cluster may be caused by the high symmetry of the (3,4)-connected [Ag4(4,4'-tpcb)3] n  4n+ cubic net. Similar facts were observed for the other anion/water clusters such as the [C2O4 2-⋅(H2O)2] n  chain reported by Mak and the [Cl(H2O)4]- cluster reported by Custelcean. To the best of our knowledge, the [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4- cluster anion has not been reported previously.

elements.content: According to Wells, the cationic [Ag4(4,4′-tpcb)3] n 4n+ net of 2 can be simplified and considered as a (3,4)-connected framework based on each Ag as a 3-connecting node and each 4,4′-tpcb as a 4-connecting node. The two types of nodes are linked to each other to form an infinite net with a vertex symbol of (6·6·6)(62·62·8·8·8·8). Taking the stoichiometry into account, the Schlafli symbol denotes the (63)4(6284)3 topology (Figure g). Such a Schlafli symbol is the same as that observed in [Cu3(tpt)4](ClO4)3·solvate (tpt = 2,4,6-tri(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine). In the latter complex, the 3-connecting node is tridentate tpt ligands, while the 4-connecting node is tetrahedrally coordinated Cu center. However, the 3- and 4-connecting nodes in 2 are pyramidally coordinated Ag ions and tetradentate ligands, respectively. To our knowledge, 2 is the first example possessing a (3,4)-connected cubic net assembled by tetradentate ligands and pyramidally 3-connecting metal ions. The two pairs of opposite pyridyl groups of one 4,4′-tpcb molecule in 2 are symmetrically arranged, which result in a C 2 axis of symmetry and two symmetrical faces in 4,4′-tpcb ligand. This is unprecedented that the flexible ligand 4,4′-tpcb displays such a high symmetry. Although the net includes 3-connecting nodes, there are striking similarities with the diamond net. The net may be obtained from the diamond net by removing 1/8 of the 4-connecting nodes, leaving a net composed of 3- and 4-connecting nodes in a ratio of 4:3. This similarity with diamond is evident with the presence of adamantane-type units within the structure (). If the anion/water cluster (which is situated around a site of −43m symmetry) was considered as a 4-connecting node which formed links to the neighboring Ag centers, the resulting net would have the topology of diamond.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis () revealed that 1 is stable up to 228 °C. The TGA curve of 1a is almost the same as 1. The final residue was assumed to be Ag2O. Compound 2 showed a first weight loss of 5.81% in the range of 60−180 °C, which corresponds to three H2O molecules per formula unit and is consistent with the formula of {{[Ag4(4,4′-tpcb)3][(NO3)4(H2O)6]}0.5} n . Compound 2 is stable up to 216 °C. When the temperature rises, a series of decomposition steps commence, and the decomposition residual species is assumed to be Ag2O.

Thermal Properties

Thermogravimetric analysis () revealed that 1 is stable up to 228 °C. The TGA curve of 1a is almost the same as 1. The final residue was assumed to be Ag2O. Compound 2 showed a first weight loss of 5.81% in the range of 60-180 °C, which corresponds to three H2O molecules per formula unit and is consistent with the formula of {{[Ag4(4,4'-tpcb)3][(NO3)4(H2O)6]}0.5} n . Compound 2 is stable up to 216 °C. When the temperature rises, a series of decomposition steps commence, and the decomposition residual species is assumed to be Ag2O.

elements.content: In the work reported here, we have demonstrated that a unique 3D cationic coordination polymer with nitrate−water cluster [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4− anions in its cages was prepared through the photochemical cycloaddition of a 1D polymer 1 followed by a hydrothermal treatment in 6 M HNO3. The nitrate−water cluster is stabilized and orderly arranged by hydrogen bonds which display high symmetry. The formation of [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4− anions may be determined by the cooperative result of suitable size, symmetry, and host−guest match between the cationic cage and the anionic water cluster. Such cluster anion may provide insight into the nature of hydration of nitrate in H2O. It is anticipated that this methodology may be applicable to the assembly of other high-dimensional cationic nets with cages or grids of different sizes to encapsulate appropriate anionic water clusters.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In the work reported here, we have demonstrated that a unique 3D cationic coordination polymer with nitrate-water cluster [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4- anions in its cages was prepared through the photochemical cycloaddition of a 1D polymer 1 followed by a hydrothermal treatment in 6 M HNO3. The nitrate-water cluster is stabilized and orderly arranged by hydrogen bonds which display high symmetry. The formation of [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4- anions may be determined by the cooperative result of suitable size, symmetry, and host-guest match between the cationic cage and the anionic water cluster. Such cluster anion may provide insight into the nature of hydration of nitrate in H2O. It is anticipated that this methodology may be applicable to the assembly of other high-dimensional cationic nets with cages or grids of different sizes to encapsulate appropriate anionic water clusters.

To a 10 mL Pyrex glass tube was loaded AgNO3 (17 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,4-BDC (17 mg, 0.1 mmol), bpe (18 mg, 0.1 mmol), and 3 mL of H2O. After the pH value was adjusted to 3.0 by addition of HNO3 (6 M), the tube was sealed and heated in an oven to 170 °C for 1 day, and then cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C h−1 to form light yellow blocks of 1, which were washed with ethanol and dried in air. Yield: 29 mg (64% yield based on Ag). Anal. calcd. for C20H15N2O4Ag: C, 52.77; H, 3.32; N, 6.15. Found: C, 52.92; H, 3.11; N, 6.18. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3436m, 3041w, 1689m, 1610s, 1559m, 1504w, 1432m, 1385m, 1255m, 1222w, 1071w, 1024w, 980m, 830s, 803w, 760s, 569m, 554s. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6, 298 K, TMS): δ = 8.61 (s, 8H, Py−H), 8.01 (s, 8H, Ph−H), 7.63 (d, 8H, Py−H), 7.53 (s, 4H, CHCH).

The crystalline powder of 1 was irradiated by a Hg lamp (400 W) for about 5 h to form a yellow product (1a). The elemental analytic result of 1a is similar to 1 (Found: C, 52.99; H, 3.45; N, 6.01). Within the crystal there are two symmetry-related interpenetrating networks, which results in the formation of smaller cages with dimensions of 8.77 × 8.77 × 11.37 Å3 (Figure d). Each of these cages is occupied by the four nitrate counteranions and six water molecules. The striking feature of these guests is that every NO3 - ion connects with three H2O molecules and every H2O molecule is linked by two NO3 - ions via O2-H1W⋅⋅⋅O1 hydrogen bonds (O2⋅⋅⋅O1 2.89 Å, O2-H1w⋅⋅⋅O1 151.7°). These hydrogen bonding interactions form a rare nitrate-water cluster anion [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4-, which has three C 2 axes going through the O atoms of water molecules (Figure e) and four C 3 axes going through the N atoms of the nitrates (Figure f). The symmetry of the [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4- cluster may be caused by the high symmetry of the (3,4)-connected [Ag4(4,4'-tpcb)3] n  4n+ cubic net. Similar facts were observed for the other anion/water clusters such as the [C2O4 2-⋅(H2O)2] n  chain reported by Mak and the [Cl(H2O)4]- cluster reported by Custelcean. To the best of our knowledge, the [(NO3)4(H2O)6]4- cluster anion has not been reported previously.

Thermal Properties

Thermogravimetric analysis () revealed that 1 is stable up to 228 °C. The TGA curve of 1a is almost the same as 1. The final residue was assumed to be Ag2O. Compound 2 showed a first weight loss of 5.81% in the range of 60-180 °C, which corresponds to three H2O molecules per formula unit and is consistent with the formula of {{[Ag4(4,4'-tpcb)3][(NO3)4(H2O)6]}0.5} n . Compound 2 is stable up to 216 °C. When the temperature rises, a series of decomposition steps commence, and the decomposition residual species is assumed to be Ag2O.

decomposition temperature.condition: corresponds to three H2O molecules per formula unit
